content:
Following #17369, which I just merged, here's what our "select language" panel looks like:

image.png

(Before that PR, the string was both not tagged for translation, and also didn't explain what the numbers mean).

I think we could probably make further improvements here. @Alya Abbott FYI, since the other big benefit of that PR is moving the link from pointing to Transifex to pointing to our translation guidelines, which is important for new volunteers actually seeing our instructions.

About the language selecting modal, I suggest separating the percentages to make it easier to find the one.
I propose the UI like this.
5c014beb5b1fd311ba418cf88540a229d01c860a.gif
ScreenShot-2023-01-25-9.13.15.jpg
ScreenShot-2023-01-25-9.13.44.jpg

Before
ScreenShot-2023-01-25-9.37.20.jpg
I opened a PR for this.

Thanks for the suggestion! I'm not sure about the exact pill shape, but something like that could work.

Thoughts on how best to handle right-to-left languages? Note that we currently list percentages on the left for those.

Given that we're left-justifying all the name-plus-percentage strings anyway, I'm not sure that having the percentages for RTL languages at the left is actually helpful for people looking for one of those languages.

Thoughts on how best to handle right-to-left languages?

I don't know the customs about those languages, so I'd like to hear others' opinions.
Replace percentages with color-coded progress bars?

Taiki Choda said:

Thoughts on how best to handle right-to-left languages?

I don't know the customs about those languages, so I'd like to hear others' opinions.

(Just to unpack my comment above more explicitly: I think the existing handling of right-to-left languages is probably not good, and any tabular form along the lines of your screenshots is probably a bigger improvement for them than it is for left-to-right languages.

But also I don't love the percentages in the first place, and a bigger change like Anders Kaseorg suggests could be a good one anyway.)

I tried it out.

ScreenShot-2023-01-25-12.24.16.jpg
ScreenShot-2023-01-25-12.24.36.jpg
Our column-major sorted order is easier to scan than your row-major sorted order.
Maybe try something in our current blue-purple brand color range for the bars? The green you might have seen around is from our old brand colors.

• Fixed sorting direction
  • Change the color to purple
    And what do you think about adding tooltips to the progress bars?
    It appears only when the user hovers the mouse cursor on it.

ScreenShot-2023-01-25-22.20.23.jpg
ScreenShot-2023-01-25-23.04.55.jpg
That could work... @Vlad Korobov what do you think?

It looks good! The consistent width between columns makes it easier to read languages and translation progress.

The only small thing that caught my attention was the increased indentation at the language container. image.png
Yeah, I like this direction. I think we can probably display the US English option as a full progress bar for consistency.
“n% Translated” should be “n% translated”.
Yeah, just to spell it out -- we have a sentence case capitalization policy for essentially all strings.

CleanShot-2023-01-25-at-23.06.232x.png
It is a bit problematic in terms of a layout and I don't understand why do we want a user to learn the progress on all languages.

At some point I want to return to that screen, but if you see the value in the change and you don't want to make a single scrollable filterable list I suggest to make gaps between related language and progress bars smaller:
image.png

I think it is worth considering whether the percentage, either as a progress bar or a number, is a good way to frame the quality of the translation. Like, another option would be to let you pick a language from a dropdown, and then display next to the language you selected details about the quality of the translation, which could be slightly more specific ("Web app", "Mobile app", and "Portico/API/Errors" are the categories we can distinguish today; yes I know they're not what one would want).
But like a translation that's missing just portco/api/errors can be quite good, even if it'll appear as like a 2/3 bar, the same as one that, say, just doesn't have a mobile translation at all.
Those categories seem helpful (we could just call the third one "other", and link to a help page for more details if needed).
Maybe you could pick a language and then see the translation quality before deciding whether to actually switch to it?

Right, I was thinking it'd be a smaller modal, and you just pick a language from a dropdown_list_widget, and then it display some things about the translation quality and you can pick "Save" or "Cancel" at the bottom.
Sure, that sounds reasonable to me.

This is just a prototype of the design of structure, but how about something like this?

  • I prefer the current language list modal because I can see all at once.
  • If we keep using the modal(not a dropdown) to show language options, it is not beautiful to have a small modal on over of it.
  • When you change language, there is no need to go through a modal to advertise the translation community.

ScreenShot-2023-03-11-14.29.33.jpg
Unless I'm a contributor I don't need to see all the languages at the same time. And there is no big reason to attract attention to level of localization (nothing to be proud if its not >95%)

Right, the main reason we want to surface the localization levels is if, say, you have 2-3 languages you speak similarly well, and one of them has a much better translation, it's nice to communicate that to you.

If we display the localization levels when you click on a language but before hitting save, that should be good enough.
